The Library's "Security"
-Unfeeling" and "insensitive" describe
the actions of Zan Baughan and Henry
Heath, the library's Support Services
chiefs. Yesterday, they relieved of her duties Joanne Vaughn, the morning attendant at MSE's gate. The action came after
Ms. Vaughn refused for personal reasons
to come to work an hour earlier and take
responsibility for opening the library.
Ms. Vaughn is justified in her refusal.
A middle-aged woman suffering from
some physical ailments is being asked to
play cop because the University is currently short on Campus Security officers, who
normally open up the place. She is expected to walk through Baltimore with
the library's keys and, assuming she safe-

ly arrives, be responsible for the entire
collection and the admittance of library
workers.
Heath and Baughan can respond that
other employees they asked have taken on
the new job, but that's beside the point.
Also, neither side says that Ms. Vaughn
was "fired" — but saying instead that "her
services are not needed" (because of her
refusal) misses the point too. Ms. Vaughn
was put in a position that would have engendered further security problems. It is
unsatisfactory to expect minimum-wage
employees to perform the jobs of our
Security officers. Dismissing Ms. Vaughn
because she made this realization is an
injustice.

The space below, normally filled
with letters, is now occupied otherwise.
We didn't get any letters this week. Not
one.

despair, and then, deeper despair. The

making up a few missives attacking
campus food, campus dogs, campus sports

show the true dedication and ingenuity of

readers can find fault with it? Hmmm.

void in the Hopkins microcosm

what a significant function the

days.

come because it is a place to
take a deserved break, buy a
relatively inexpensive snack or
reviving drink, and converse with
friends--a seemingly trivial, yet
profoundly important element
of daily life. The Coffee Shop's
success has been wildly hailed by
every branch of the University

of the Shop was taken away

Last week I had a horrible
nightmare: I dreamed I was a
graduate student. Seated at the
head of the table in a seminar
room, I was straining to remain
attentive to an eminent professor lecturing to me from the
blackboard while simultaneously •
delivering my own lecture to a
group of reluctant undergraduates all staring at me with
listless, bloodshot eyes. When I
spoke, the professor glared;
when I listened, my students
giggled; while all around the
room the 400-plus pages of my
dissertation on ancient numismatics were being blown around
in hectic circles before disappearing through an open door...
When I awoke, I was profusely grateful to discover that I
was still only an undergraduate.
I could not extinguish the
fearful memory of my dream,
however, and during the next
few days I found myself peering
with renewed interest at those
fleeting, bearded figures in the
halls of Gilman who I knew for a
fact to be graduate students.
Who are these people? I asked
myself.
And what are they
doing here? Where are they
going? Since no one I knew
could answer these questions, I
resolved to find out.
My preliminary investigations were fruitless, for as I soon
discovered, grads are not like
other students. They are forbidden to belong to most campus
organizations, and consequently
do not exist for (or work on the
staff of) the News-Letter. You
never see them in the Rat. Some
of them work in the Hut oc-

casionally, but not at night. I
was unable to gain admittance to
the Grad Club on Friday, where
I have been told they band
together in total privacy, doubtless to perform some dark,
mysterious rite.
True, they
consume an inordinate quantity
of coffee and doughnuts, accounting for fully half the
normal line at the Gilman Coffee
Shop, but having made their
purchases all but a few of them
hurriedly vanish, allowing only a
momentary glimpse of their
horned rim glasses and worn
tweed jackets, their shiny briefcases and smartly tailored feminine three-pice suits.
Stymied in my effort at
obtaining information through
the usual channels, I turned to
the university catalogue for help.
"Graduate students find that
their academic and social lives
tend to center around their
departments," it declared. This
was very perplexing to me,since
I had always imagined that
"departments" were populated
with "professors." Grad students, on the other hand, were
students... weren't they? Suddenly, I realized my error: a
graduate is not really a student,
but rather a college professor
struggling to be born.
I will expand on this definition shortly: for now, consider
the vast gulf that separates
professors from undergraduates.
For no matter how impossibly
dense the former, or how
intelligent the latter, the professor is always cast in the
authoritative role of "teacher,"
lecturing to or mediating under-

graduates who, presumably,
learn from him. The professors
seem comfortable with their
authorit, the undergraduates
are content to be subordinate,
and role definition, at least in
the classroom, is never a problem.
With the grad student, it is
more complicated. He must
both learn and teach, submit to
professors while dominating
undergraduates, at a time when
neither role is altogether satisfactory.
For if he anticipates
getting hired, he must concentrate less on assimilating knowledge from the professor than on
seeing how that knowledge may
be reworded; beginning with his
dissertation, he must learn to
produce "criticism" or "research" and to continue producing it indefinitely, or at least
until he be granted tenure. This
is known as "publish or perish;"
its initial effect is to induce a
gnawing uncertainty in graduate
students who are only beginning
to adjust from their relatively
carefree days as undergraduates.
Which ties in with another
problem: not all undergraduates
appreciate being taught by someone only a couple of years their
senior. They do not respect the
grad student as they do the
professor; if the grad wishes to
acquire this respect he most
forcibly dissociate himself from
his familiar role as student and
practice making pronouncements with the ringing authority
that is supposedly characteristic
of the prof.

education less than they should.

funding of schools as a contributor to the crisis. Local control

funding based on taxes have led

cities as compared with suburbs,

two-thirds of the US population
that lives in cities gets an inadequate education. Muller noted

operate expensive radar sets and
other defense equipment which
taxes pay for.
Muller's fourth point was
the amount of time wasted in
the US educational system,
which he called the "Gilmari
Syndrome". Named after the
first president of JHU, the
syndrome goes back to when
Gilman adapted the German idea
of an advanced research institution to fit into the existing
educational system, Muller said.
Mixing the two ideas resulted in
the present system which a
student must go through 12
years of schooling and 4 years of
collegiate studies if he seeks
higher education, and must
spend an additional 3 to 4 years
if he pursues graduate studies.
According to Muller, not only is
much of this time wasted
because of overlap of material,
but students are placed in a peer
group that is lax on discipline at
a time when they need it most.
Muller concluded that we
are getting about as much out of
our educational system as we
put in. More equitable funding
would improve the quality of
education, he said, and if parents
took a greater interest in their
children's studies, perhaps children would take more pride in
what they learn. Providing a
good education to as many
people as possible is very important in a society that depends

on individuals being aware and
able to make choices, he added.

society started as a group of
self-confident individuals who
set up institutions to help
themselves. He contended that
we have come to rely on institutions so much that we are losing
our self-confidence. He ended
his talk by encouraging parents
to take interest instead of
lending their children to schools
and letting them handle the
entire educational process.

Last week I had a horrible
nightmare: I dreamed I was a
graduate student. Seated at the
head of the table in a seminar
room, I was straining to remain
attentive to an eminent professor lecturing to me from the
blackboard while simultaneously •
delivering my own lecture to a
group of reluctant undergraduates all staring at me with
listless, bloodshot eyes. When I
spoke, the professor glared;
when I listened, my students
giggled; while all around the
room the 400-plus pages of my
dissertation on ancient numismatics were being blown around

When I awoke, I was profusely grateful to discover that I
was still only an undergraduate.
I could not extinguish the
fearful memory of my dream,
however, and during the next
few days I found myself peering
with renewed interest at those
fleeting, bearded figures in the
halls of Gilman who I knew for a
fact to be graduate students.
Who are these people? I asked
myself.
And what are they
doing here? Where are they
going? Since no one I knew
could answer these questions, I
resolved to find out.
My preliminary investigations were fruitless, for as I soon
discovered, grads are not like
other students. They are forbidden to belong to most campus
organizations, and consequently
do not exist for (or work on the
staff of) the News-Letter. You
never see them in the Rat. Some
of them work in the Hut oc-

casionally, but not at night. I
was unable to gain admittance to
the Grad Club on Friday, where
I have been told they band
together in total privacy, doubtless to perform some dark,
mysterious rite.
True, they
consume an inordinate quantity
of coffee and doughnuts, accounting for fully half the
normal line at the Gilman Coffee
Shop, but having made their
purchases all but a few of them
hurriedly vanish, allowing only a
momentary glimpse of their
horned rim glasses and worn
tweed jackets, their shiny briefcases and smartly tailored feminine three-pice suits.
Stymied in my effort at
obtaining information through
the usual channels, I turned to
the university catalogue for help.
"Graduate students find that
their academic and social lives
tend to center around their
departments," it declared. This
was very perplexing to me,since
I had always imagined that
"departments" were populated
with "professors." Grad students, on the other hand, were
students... weren't they? Suddenly, I realized my error: a
graduate is not really a student,
but rather a college professor
struggling to be born.
I will expand on this definition shortly: for now, consider
the vast gulf that separates
professors from undergraduates.
For no matter how impossibly
dense the former, or how
intelligent the latter, the professor is always cast in the
authoritative role of "teacher,"
lecturing to or mediating under-

graduates who, presumably,
learn from him. The professors
seem comfortable with their
authorit, the undergraduates
are content to be subordinate,
and role definition, at least in
the classroom, is never a problem.
With the grad student, it is
more complicated. He must
both learn and teach, submit to
professors while dominating
undergraduates, at a time when
neither role is altogether satisfactory.
For if he anticipates
getting hired, he must concentrate less on assimilating knowledge from the professor than on
seeing how that knowledge may
be reworded; beginning with his
dissertation, he must learn to
produce "criticism" or "research" and to continue producing it indefinitely, or at least
until he be granted tenure. This
is known as "publish or perish;"
its initial effect is to induce a
gnawing uncertainty in graduate
students who are only beginning
to adjust from their relatively
carefree days as undergraduates.
Which ties in with another
problem: not all undergraduates

senior. They do not respect the
grad student as they do the
professor; if the grad wishes to
acquire this respect he most
forcibly dissociate himself from
his familiar role as student and
practice making pronouncements with the ringing authority
that is supposedly characteristic
of the prof.

Muller said a second problem facing the academic world is
that Americans value a good
education less than they should.
Citing teachers' low salaries as an
example, he illustrated that
Americans consider education
and educators less important
than other services.
Muller also cited inequitable
funding of schools as a contributor to the crisis. Local control
of school systems, and local
funding based on taxes have led
to poor educational facilities in
cities as compared with suburbs,
he explained, adding that the
two-thirds of the US population
that lives in cities gets an inadequate education. Muller noted
that many of these young adults
operate expensive radar sets and
other defense equipment which
taxes pay for.
Muller's fourth point was
the amount of time wasted in
the US educational system,
which he called the "Gilmari
Syndrome". Named after the
first president of JHU, the
syndrome goes back to when
Gilman adapted the German idea
of an advanced research institution to fit into the existing
educational system, Muller said.
Mixing the two ideas resulted in
the present system which a
student must go through 12
years of schooling and 4 years of
collegiate studies if he seeks
higher education, and must
spend an additional 3 to 4 years
if he pursues graduate studies.
According to Muller, not only is
much of this time wasted
because of overlap of material,
but students are placed in a peer
group that is lax on discipline at
a time when they need it most.
Muller concluded that we
are getting about as much out of
our educational system as we
put in. More equitable funding
would improve the quality of
education, he said, and if parents
took a greater interest in their
children's studies, perhaps children would take more pride in
what they learn. Providing a
good education to as many
people as possible is very important in a society that depends

on individuals being aware and
able to make choices, he added.
Finally, Muller said our
society started as a group of
self-confident individuals who
set up institutions to help
themselves. He contended that
we have come to rely on institutions so much that we are losing
our self-confidence. He ended
his talk by encouraging parents
to take interest instead of
lending their children to schools
and letting them handle the
entire educational process.
